Words cannot begin to express the sheer power of how great this game is. The storyline is so fascinating and the environment is pretty appealing. The weapons are great fun and half the time you'll find yourself struggling to decide which two guns to carry with you, you'll also be looting the hell out of everywhere you pass looking for money, lockpicks, and secrets! If you don't explore carefully - you could miss something important! 

The game plays out with a satisfying mixture of gameplay and immersive cutscenes that don't bore you to death or drone on for ages. It plays nicely because it's not a constant gunfight, and even if it is in some places, guns are not the only thing to your disposal, you can yield an arsenal of dangerously exciting powers otherwise known as Vigors which grant you supernatural abilities to summon molten fire balls from, electrical shards, or even absorb and throw your enemies bullets back all from your very hands!

A plethora of weaponry and Vigors will keep you fighting through this game and it's many villians such as the guards and police of Columbia to the Handyman, to the Mechanical Patriots that will tear you down with a devestating Crank Gun (OTHERWISE KNOWN AS A MINIGUN!)

This game has such a captivating storyline and will keep players going for a while, it's not a game you can or should rush through so hastefully, and careful decisions of Elizabeths Tear powers, weapon and vigor upgrades and how you dismiss your foes are entirely down to you and how you wish to experience your time in the majestic world of Columbia!

i have mixed opinions in this game. the setting and the aesthetic and a lot of the themes explored are really interesting and cool, but the gameplay feels completely separate from whats going on in the plot and there are a lot of mechanics that really break the immersion. you can just hit a key that tells you where to go, which you have to do a lot because of confusing level layouts, the combat segments get very formulaeic and repetitive after a while, and the fact that you can just singlehandedly gun down hundreds and hundreds of grunts without much of a problem just doesn't make logical sense in the context of the story and your character. it's also really weird that elizabeth is just fucking invincible throughout the whole game, even in the crazy firefights where she's just running through barrages of bullets and nothings happening, and she somehow has the ability to pull supplies out of thin air and throw them to you during combat. the actual combat isn't particularly mindblowing either, it feels like a very standard FPS game without much new to bring to the table. the vigor abilities and the skylines are pretty interesting and fun at first but they didn't stop the combat from getting repetitive in the long run for me. if you're willing to power through very average FPS gameplay for an interesting narrative experience, or you're just particularly fond of FPS games and don't mind if the gameplay isn't very original, i'd recommend this game, but otherwise you should maybe reconsider.

BioShock Infinite is a great game. An awesome successor to the original BioShock. It's not as much of a sequel though. Not saying BioShock 2 wasn't good, and BioShock was amazing, but this game.... It's surpassed my expectations immensly. It plays the same, with the same feel of gameplay. They incorperate Vigors, like the original Plasmid, very well into the game. Columbia and Rapture also have the same-ish creation story, too. Except.... Rapture was 'No Gods, No Kings, Only Man', whereas Columbia was created when an angel came down from heaven and told Comstock to create Columbia (so it's 100% religious). Although there is no 'Little Sister' type character, it does feel good to not have 2 or 3 Big Daddies per section. When you actually get to Columbia, via a rocket in a lighthouse (go figure), it isn't in ruins. It feels good to see that it doesnt start like the other games. It really seems like the polar opposite of Rapture. Not in ruins, and in the sky. It does take place in 1912, yet it still gives the feeling of modern times, given the fact that both cities (Rapture and Columbia), are ahead of their time by at least 20 or 30 years. They do a good job with the light, sort of peaceful atmosphere that Columbia produces. It is very different from Rapture, yet the game still feels like the first and second BioShock. With new weapons, and different types of power-ups (Plasmids and Vigors), this game is excellent. So, get out of the dreary, gloomy, splicer ridden city of Rapture, and move to the happy, safe, splicer free (there is no splicer like enemies either, huh), floating city of Columbia!

This is the first review I've written on Steam, and cosidering I have roughly 50 games and I've never bothered to write one before, and yet I'd bother to write one for a game that already has 11,000 reviews says something right there. 

Bioshock as a universe has always been hauntingly gripping. The stark contrasts of beautiful scenery mixed with shocking violence, grief tinged narratives, and perfectly melancholy music mixed with conclusions you never see coming are only a fraction of what make Bioshock and Bioshock Infinite so remarkable (I don't know if Bioshock 2 counts). Odds are, if you're looking at this game, you already know something about Bioshock or have already played a Bioshock game, and I won't bother repeating what thousands of other people have already said. 

As far as the world goes, I think the original Bioshock was far better. There was much more of a feel of a otherworldy, but somehow still oddly believable, fallen utopian feel to the world of Rapture that I don't think Columbia ever achieves, as beautiful as it is. Also, the actual developing storyline and villians of the original Bioshock definitely trump Inifinite. 

But where Inifinite soars is through it's characters. This is perhaps the first game I've ever played where I honestly could have completely hated the gameplay and still adored this game (and the gameplay is still great, don't worry). The way that Inifite pulls you in, without the starting and stopping and jolting nature of cutscenes or in your face narratives is amazing. You find yourself in the characters, with them in a way that I can't compare to another game, and before you know it, you're pulled in, you feel like you're part of them. I'm sure that many people have remarked about the story, or the ending, etc, but the reason that those things will affect you so much is because of who's eyes you see it through. The intensity and depth of the 2 main characters and the way you get to experience their journey through this game has left me with a hole after I finished this game that I don't think any other game can fill. 

So I'll just join the club and say get the game. Enjoy the game, but fall in love the the story and the people in it. Because I get a sneaking suspicion that was the real goal in the first place.

If you like shooting things, if you like crazy powers, if you like an actually useful video game companion, and if you'd like a story that makes your brain instinctively go OMGWTFBBQ then you should probably get this game already.
